incorporation_agency: Illinois Secretary of State - Business Services Department
charitable_registration_agency: Illinois Attorney General - Charitable Trust and Solicitation Bureau
exemption_threshold_note: Organizations with contributions under $15,000 annually that do not use professional fundraisers may be exempt from registration. Religious organizations and certain educational institutions are also exempt.

formation_requirements.notes: Illinois requires a registered agent with a physical Illinois address. The registered agent can be an individual resident or a business entity authorized to do business in Illinois.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Secretary of State - Business Services Department
requirements.due_date_specifics: Due during the anniversary month of incorporation (first day of month)
required_information: Names and addresses of directors and officers
requirements.notes: Filing is required annually during anniversary month. Late fee of $100 applies. Failure to file for two consecutive years results in involuntary dissolution.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Attorney General - Charitable Trust and Solicitation Bureau
required_information: List of officers, directors, and trustees
requirements.notes: Registration required before soliciting in Illinois if contributions exceed $15,000 or professional fundraiser is used. Religious organizations and certain others are exempt.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Attorney General - Charitable Trust and Solicitation Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 6 months after fiscal year end
requirements.notes: Organizations with gross support under $25,000 may file simplified report. Late filing may result in compliance actions but no monetary penalty.

requirements.requirement_name: Illinois Sales Tax Exemption Identification Number
requirements.due_date_specifics: Apply after receiving IRS 501(c)(3) determination letter
requirements.form_number: Form REG-1 - Illinois Business Registration Application
requirements.notes: Illinois 501(c)(3) organizations are exempt from sales tax on purchases for charitable purposes. Register with IDOR to receive exemption identification number (E-number). Provide E-number to vendors with Form CRT-61.

requirements.filing_agency: County Board of Review or Board of Appeals
requirements.due_date_specifics: File before assessment date (varies by county, typically January 1st)
requirements.form_number: Varies by county - Application for Property Tax Exemption
required_information: Description of property use for exempt purposes
requirements.notes: Illinois property tax exemption requires exclusive use for charitable purposes. Property cannot produce income exceeding costs of maintenance and operation. Once granted, exemption continues if use remains charitable.

requirements.filing_agency: Local Municipal or County Clerk (or Illinois Department of Revenue for state-wide)
requirements.due_date_specifics: File application at least 30 days before raffle event
required_information: Proof of incorporation or 5+ years operation in Illinois
List of officers and raffle managers
requirements.legal_citation: 230 ILCS 15/ - Raffles and Poker Runs Act
requirements.notes: Illinois allows raffles for nonprofits organized in Illinois for 5+ years. Manager license required ($5 per manager). Annual raffle prize limit $300,000. Statewide raffles require IDOR license. Single event raffles limited to $75,000 in prizes.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Department of Revenue - Charitable Games Division
requirements.due_date_specifics: License valid for calendar year; renew annually
required_information: Proof of 5+ years operation in Illinois
List of officers and game managers
Description of games to be conducted
requirements.legal_citation: 230 ILCS 30/ - Illinois Pull Tabs and Jar Games Act
requirements.notes: Required for pull tabs, jar games, and other charitable games. Organization must be in existence for 5+ years. Proceeds must be used for lawful purposes. Annual reporting required.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Attorney General - Charitable Trust and Solicitation Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Renewed annually from initial registration date
requirements.form_number: Form PFC-1 - Professional Fund Raiser Registration
requirements.notes: Required for paid professional fundraisers who solicit on behalf of charities. Each contract must be filed within 10 days. Bond must remain in force during registration period.

requirements.filing_agency: Illinois Attorney General - Charitable Trust and Solicitation Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Renewed annually from initial registration date
requirements.form_number: Form FRC-1 - Fund Raising Counsel Registration
requirements.notes: Fundraising counsel provides consulting but does not solicit or handle contributions. No bond required. Each contract must be filed within 10 days of execution.

requirements.filing_agency: Internal requirement - filed with board and included in AG990-IL filing if required
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 180 days after fiscal year end (completed before AG990-IL due date)
requirements.notes: Illinois requires audited financial statements for organizations with gross support over $300,000. Organizations between $100,000-$300,000 must have financial review. Organizations under $100,000 may file internally prepared statements. Audit must be performed by independent CPA.

special_notes.registration_thresholds: Illinois has a $15,000 contribution threshold for charitable registration. Organizations under $15,000 without professional fundraisers are exempt from registration but not from other laws.
special_notes.annual_filing_fees: Both initial registration and annual renewal fees are $15 for charitable organizations, making Illinois one of the most affordable states for compliance.
special_notes.board_requirements: Illinois nonprofit corporations must have at least three directors. Directors need not be Illinois residents. Board must meet requirements specified in bylaws.
special_notes.five_year_rule: Illinois gaming laws require organizations to be in existence for at least 5 years before conducting raffles or charitable games. This is longer than most states.
special_notes.raffle_prize_limits: Illinois raffles have specific prize limits: $75,000 for single event raffles, $300,000 aggregate for all raffles per year. Statewide raffles have different rules.
special_notes.political_activity_limits: 501(c)(3) organizations must comply with federal restrictions on political campaign intervention and lobbying activities. Illinois reinforces these federal limits.
special_notes.professional_fundraiser_contracts: All contracts with professional fundraisers or fundraising counsel must be filed with the Attorney General within 10 days of execution.
special_notes.charitable_trust_reporting: Illinois requires charitable trusts to register and report separately. Organizations holding assets in trust have additional reporting obligations.
special_notes.audit_threshold: Illinois audit threshold is $300,000 in gross support. This is mid-range compared to other states. Review threshold is $100,000.
special_notes.dissolution_requirements: Upon dissolution, assets must be distributed to organizations with similar charitable purposes. Attorney General must be notified of dissolution plans.
special_notes.unrelated_business_income: Organizations with unrelated business income over $1,000 must file IRS Form 990-T and Illinois Corporate Income and Replacement Tax (IL-1041) if conducting business in Illinois.
special_notes.sales_tax_exemption_use: To claim sales tax exemption, nonprofits must provide vendors with Form CRT-61 (Sales Tax Exemption Certificate) along with their E-number.
special_notes.property_tax_strictness: Illinois property tax exemption requires actual charitable use. Property producing net income may not qualify even if owned by nonprofit.
